fields.name: age
fields.title: Age of participants
fields.description: The answer to the question,  "How old are you?"

fields.name: gender
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Gender:"
the question had four answer categories:
"Male", "Female", "Other", "Prefer not to say"
fields.title: Gender of participants

fields.name: position
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "I currently self-identify as…"
The question had six answer categories:
"Academic", "Archevist", "Independent Scholar", "Librarian", "PhD researcher", "Student"
fields.title: Academic positions

fields.name: years_experience
fields.description: The answer to the question, "How many years of experience do you have in your current position?"
fields.title: Experience in position

fields.name: field
fields.description: The answer to the question, "What is your academic field?"
fields.title: Academic field

fields.name: familiarity
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Are you familiar with the term ‘Open data’?"
The question had two answer categories: "Yes" and "No"
fields.title: Familiarity with open data

fields.name: familiarity_scource
fields.description: The answer to the question, "If you are, where do you know it from?"
fields.title: Scource of familiarity

fields.name: importance
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Using the definition above, how important do you believe creating and using open data is for research today?"
The 'definition' refers to "(...)data that can be freely used, shared and built-on by anyone, anywhere, for any purpose." (Laura James 2016, link: https://blog.okfn.org/2013/10/03/defining-open-data/)
The question had five answer categories: "Not important", "Slightly important", "Neutral", "Important", "Very important"
fields.title: Importance of open data

fields.name: definition_comment
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Is your definition of open data different from the one used above? If it is, how so?"
The 'definition' refers to "(...)data that can be freely used, shared and built-on by anyone, anywhere, for any purpose." (Laura James 2016, link: https://blog.okfn.org/2013/10/03/defining-open-data/)
fields.title: Comment on a definition of open data

fields.name: share_after_pub
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Do you believe it is important in your field to share data after publication?"
The question had two answer categories: "Yes" and "No"
fields.title: Importance of data sharing after publication

fields.name: share_after_pub_comment
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Write the reason for your answer"
This question refers to the previous question (see: Importance of data sharing after publication)
fields.title: commpent on the importance of sharing data after publication

fields.name: share_after_pub_freq
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "In the last 24 months, how often have you shared your data after publication?"
The question had 5 answer categories: "Always", "Often", "Sometimes", "Rarely", "Never"
fields.title: Frequency of sharing data after publication

fields.name: share_pre_pub
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Do you believe it is important in your field to share data before publication?"
The question had two answer categories: "Yes" and "No"
fields.title: Importance of sharing data before publication

fields.name: share_pre_pub_comment
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "Write the reason for your answer"
This question refers to the previous question (see: Importance of data sharing before publication)
fields.title: Comment on the importance of sharing data before publication

fields.name: share_pre_pub_freq
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "In the last 24 months, how often have you shared your data before publication?"
The question had 5 answer categories: "Always", "Often", "Sometimes", "Rarely", "Never"
fields.title: Frequency of sharing data after publication

fields.name: public_data_freq
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "In the last 24 months, how often have you made the data and/or data analysis scripts of your research projects public?
(ie. shared them in a data-base or online repository, as opposed to sharing the data only when asked)"
The question had 5 answer categories: "Always", "Often", "Sometimes", "Rarely", "Never"
fields.title: Frequency of making data public

fields.name: public_data_how
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "How are the data/scripts shared?"
This question refers to the previous question (see: Frequency of making data public)
fields.title: How is the data public

fields.name: student_graded
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "(For students) Are you graded in your subjects for adherence to open science principles?"
The question had three answer categories: "Yes", "No", "Not relevant for me"
fields.title: Open data grading (students)

fields.name: teacher_graded
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "(For teachers) Do you grade your students for adherence to open science principles?"
The question had three answer categories: "Yes", "No", "Not relevant for me"
fields.title: Open data grading (teachers)

fields.name: other_data_use
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "In the past 24 months, how often have you used other people’s data for your own research? (Class work included)"
The question had 5 answer categories: "Always", "Often", "Sometimes", "Rarely", "Never"
fields.title: Use of other peoples' data

fields.name: other_data_experience
fields.description:
The answer to the question, "If you have, what was your experience?"
This question refers to the previous question (see: Use of other peoples' data)
fields.title: Experience with using other peoples' data

fields.name: status
fields.title: Status
fields.description:
Variable indicating the completion status of the survey. The variable has two lables
"complete" = participant clicked 'submit' on the last page of the survey.
"incomplete" = participant quit survey prior to doing so.

name: survey_data_package
title: Survey on open data at Aarhus University
description: Cleaned data from a small survey of data sharing attitudes and practices at Aarhus University, Denmark
